description: Planned availability is a quality that describes the amount of time a power plant is planned to be operational per year.

nodes.name: battery electric truck
description: A battery electric truck is a truck that has an electric traction motor and a traction battery and thus is also a battery electric vehicle.

nodes.name: fossil energy
description: Fossil energy is chemical energy that is stored in fossil combustion fuels and thus has a conventional origin.

nodes.name: plug-in hybrid electric vehicle
description: A plug-in hybrid electric vehicle (PHEV) is a vehicle that contains both an electric traction motor and an internal combustion engine and can switch between their usage for propulsion. It contains a traction battery that can be charged with electrical energy from an external supply.

nodes.name: direct equivalent method
description: A direct equivalent method is a primary energy consumption calculation method that quantifies renewable and nuclear energies using its secondary energy content assuming no conversion losses.

nodes.name: primary energy consumption calculation method
description: A primary energy consumption calculation method is a methodology to calculate primary energy consumption.

nodes.name: levy
description: A levy is a policy instrument that consists of a compulsory financial charge imposed on an agent or institution by a governmental organisation.

nodes.name: passenger port
description: A passenger port is a port for the exchange of passengers.

nodes.name: hub height
description: Hub height is a quality of a wind energy converting unit that measures the distance between surface and centre-line of the wind rotor.

nodes.name: sustainable biofuel
description: A sustainable biofuel is a biofuel that does conform to sustainability criteria.

nodes.name: system cost
description: System cost are total costs of a system.

nodes.name: recovered heat
description: Recovered heat is a thermal energy that is physical output of an energy transformation process and that is recovered and would otherwise be emitted in the environment as waste thermal energy.

nodes.name: kilowatt-hour
description: "An energy unit which is equal to 1,000 watt-hours." [Wikipedia:Wikipedia]

nodes.name: client
description: A client is an agent that receives a product or service.

nodes.name: compressed biomethane
description: Compressed biomethane is biomethane that has been compressed.

nodes.name: conventional energy
description: A conventional energy is an energy that has a conventional origin.

nodes.name: capacity premium
description: A capacity premium is a market premium that guarantees remuneration for reserving capacity of energy transformation units to be available for unexpected events.

nodes.name: compressed gas car
description: A compressed gas car is a car that uses compressed gas in a gas engine for propulsion and thus is also a compressed gas vehicle.

nodes.name: fissile material entity
description: A fissile material entity is a material entity that has the disposition to carry nuclear (binding) energy.

nodes.name: fuel power technology
description: A fuel-powered generation technology is a power technology that describes how to combine fuel-powered units in a fuel-powered electricity generation process.

nodes.name: areal energy density unit
description: An areal energy density unit is a unit which is a measure for the energy per surface area.

nodes.name: non-sustainable biofuel
description: A non-sustainable biofuel is a biofuel that does not conform to sustainability criteria.

nodes.name: solver
description: A solver is a software that solves a mathematical problem.

nodes.name: container ship
description: A container ship is a cargo ship used for the transport of containers.

nodes.name: diesel vehicle
description: A diesel vehicle is an internal combustion vehicle that has only a diesel engine as motor for propulsion.

nodes.name: length unit
description: "A unit which is a standard measure of the distance between two points." [Wikipedia:Wikipedia]

nodes.name: marine tidal energy
description: Marine tidal energy is the natural hydro energy of a tidal flow.

nodes.name: water electrolyser
description: A water electrolyser is an energy converting component that uses an electric current to decompose water into hydrogen and oxygen gas. Electrical energy is converted into chemical energy (and waste heat).

nodes.name: electrical energy share value
description: An electrical energy share value is a fraction value that quantifies the share of electrical energy (degree of electrification).

nodes.name: gaseous renewable fuel
description: A gaseous renewable fuel is a renewable fuel that has a gaseous state of matter under normal conditions.

nodes.name: solid combustion fuel
description: A solid combustion fuel is a combustion fuel that has a solid state of matter under normal conditions.

nodes.name: sustainable process
description: A sustainable process is a process that has a process sustainability attribute.

nodes.name: purchasing power parity
description: Purchasing power parity is an economic value representing the ratio between currencies that equalises differences in monetary price levels between countries for the same set of goods.

nodes.name: marine tidal energy converting unit
description: A marine tidal energy converting unit is a hydro power unit that uses marine tidal energy.

nodes.name: power-to-ammonia process
description: A power-to-ammonia process is a power-to-gas process that has ammonia as output.

nodes.name: hydrogen turbine
description: A hydrogen turbine is a gas turbine fueled with hydrogen.

nodes.name: marine thermal energy transfer
description: Marine thermal energy transfer is a heat transfer from the marine water body to a transportable material entity.

nodes.name: sender
description: A sender is an agent who initiates a communication.

nodes.name: process profile
description: b is a process_profile =Def. there is some process c such that b process_profile_of c (axiom label in BFO2 Reference: [093-002])

nodes.name: checking against empirical data
description: Checking against empirical data is a validation where something gets checked against empirical data.

nodes.name: plug-in hybrid electric car
description: A plug-in hybrid electric car is a car that can switch between an electric traction motor and an internal combustion engine for propulsion and thus is also a plug-in hybrid electric vehicle.

nodes.name: distribution
description: Distribution is the process of delivering goods and services to agents. ETst

nodes.name: traction
description: Traction is a process of pushing or pulling to drive an object.

nodes.name: oxidation
description: Oxidation is a chemical reaction that describes the loss of electrons of an atom, an ion, or of certain atoms in a molecule and is a part of a redox reaction.

nodes.name: person
description: A person is a human being.

nodes.name: electro motive generator
description: An electro motive generator is a generator that converts kinetic energy into electric energy.

nodes.name: working age population
description: The working age population is the population of people aged 15 to 65.

nodes.name: heat generation process
description: A heat generation process is an energy transformation that has thermal energy as energy output.

nodes.name: solar thermal power unit
description: A solar thermal power unit is a solar power unit that has solar thermal collectors as parts.

nodes.name: nationally determined contribution
description: A nationally determined contribution (NDC) is a target description of future greenhouse gas emission reductions prepared, communicated and maintained by a party to the Paris Agreement.

nodes.name: jet fuel vehicle
description: A jet fuel vehicle is a gas turbine vehicle that uses a jet fuel turbine.

nodes.name: gas turbine vehicle
description: A gas turbine vehicle is a vehicle that uses a gas turbine for propulsion.

nodes.name: bidirectional vehicle charging station
description: A bidirectional vehicle charging station is a vehicle charging station that can also feed electrical energy from the traction battery back into the electricity grid.

nodes.name: comma separated file format
description: A comma separated file format is a delimiter separated file format that uses comma (,) as delimiter.

nodes.name: current collector
description: A current collector is an energy converting component that transfers electrical energy between a stationary conductor and a grid supplied electric vehicle.

nodes.name: coke oven gas
description: Coke oven gas is manufactured coal based gas obtained as a by-product of the manufacture of coke oven coke for the production of iron and steel.

nodes.name: substitution method
description: A substitution method is a primary energy consumption calculation method that treats renewable energy carriers as if they have similar conversion losses as a specified fossil reference energy carrier.

nodes.name: blended liquid fuel
description: A blended liquid fuel is a liquid combustion fuel that contains a liquid fossil fuel and a liquid renewable fuel or a liquid biofuel.

nodes.name: liquefied petroleum gas vehicle
description: A liquefied petroleum gas vehicle is a gas vehicle that uses liquefied petroleum gas as fuel.

nodes.name: plotting
description: Plotting is data processing where data is visualised in form of a diagram.

nodes.name: paper
description: Paper is a portion of matter that is made from cellulose fibres and other plant materials. It is used for paper-based products. It has a solid normal state of matter. It is the physical output of an industrial process and has a commodity role.

nodes.name: heating grid component
description: A heating grid component is a grid component that is part of a heating grid.

nodes.name: solar receiving object
description: A solar receiving object is an artificial object that has a solar radiation receiving surface as part.

nodes.name: Western Texas Intermediate
description: Western Texas Intermediate (WTI) is a crude oil that is extracted on US territory and traded at NYMEX New York.

nodes.name: objective function
description: An objective function is an information content entity stating the function that should be maximised or minimised to solve a problem.

nodes.name: open-loop pumped hydro storage power plant
description: An open-loop pumped hydro storage power plant is a pumped hydro storage power plant that has natural inflows.

nodes.name: fluorinated greenhouse gas
description: A fluorinated greenhouse gas is a greenhouse gas that is produced by fluorination. Hence it contains Fluor (F) atoms and is of anthropogenic origin.

nodes.name: greenhouse gas
description: A greenhouse gas is a portion of matter that has the disposition to contribute to the greenhouse effect.

nodes.name: solar-steam-electric process
description: A solar-steam-electric process is a solar energy transformation that converts solar energy into electrical energy. It has two partial processes: a solar thermal energy transformation and a steam-electric process.

nodes.name: steam reforming hydrogen
description: Steam reforming hydrogen is hydrogen that is a physical output of a steam reforming process.

nodes.name: primary energy carrier mining
description: Primary energy carrier mining is a primary energy production that recovers non-renewable energy carriers from its natural site.

nodes.name: nameplate capacity
description: Nameplate capacity is the power capacity stating the maximum power an artificial object, e.g. a power generating unit or a power plant, can generate, and the sum of the power ratings of all energy converting component of that power plant.

nodes.name: bioenergy
description: Bioenergy is chemical energy that is stored in biofuels.

nodes.name: electricity generation function
description: An electricity generation function is an energy transformation function to transform other types of energy to electrical energy.

nodes.name: kilo ton of coal equivalent
description: A kilo ton of coal equivalent is an energy unit which is equal to 1,000 tons of coal equivalent.

nodes.name: fuel demand
description: Fuel demand is the energy demand for fuel.

nodes.name: solar thermal heat technology
description: A solar thermal heat technology is a heat generation technology that describes how to combine solar heat units, solar thermal energy transformation processes, energy carriers and energy in a specific way.

nodes.name: fuel cost
description: A fuel cost is a variable cost that depends on the type and amount of fuel.

nodes.name: natural gas turbine
description: A natural gas turbine is a gas turbine fueled with natural gas.

nodes.name: energy conversion performance
description: Energy conversion performance is a process attribute describing the ratio between the non-heat input of an energy transformation and the outputs that are used.

nodes.name: remuneration
description: A remuneration is an economic value that describes a financial compensation provided in exchange for services performed.

nodes.name: scenario projection comparison
description: A scenario comparison study is a scenario study that performs a scenario projection comparison

nodes.name: liquid fossil fuel
description: A liquid fossil fuel is a fossil combustion fuel that has a liquid state of matter under normal conditions.

nodes.name: water flow rate
description: Water flow rate is the process attribute of water flow that quantifies the water volume per time unit.

nodes.name: electricity export value
description: An electricity import value is an electrical energy amount value that measures the import of electrical energy.

nodes.name: renewable
description: Renewable is an origin of energies that replenish on a human time scale.

nodes.name: ratio
description: "A dimensionless ratio unit which, given a pair of quantities a and b, for which b is a multiple of a, denotes b by giving the multiplier (coefficient) c for a to result in b." [UOB:LKSR]

nodes.name: Annual Emission Allocation
description: An Annual Emission Allocation (AEA) is an emission certificate used in the Effort Sharing Decision (ESD) and the Effort Sharing Regulation (ESR). It permits the emission of a CO2 equivalent quantity of 1 tonne.

nodes.name: freight port
description: A freight port is a port for the exchange of goods.

nodes.name: hydrogen station
description: A hydrogen station is a filling station that transfers hydrogen.

nodes.name: electricity import
description: Electricity import is the import of electrical energy.

nodes.name: geothermal power plant
description: A geothermal power plant is a power plant that has geothermal power units as parts.

nodes.name: data licence
description: A data licence is a licence that determines ownership, database protection, and permissions for data.

nodes.name: trade
description: A trade is a process in which one good or service is exchanged for another good or service or money.

nodes.name: agriculture, forestry and land use sector
description: A agriculture, forestry and land use (AFOLU) sector is a sector that covers activities and natural processes from agriculture, forestry, land use and land use change.

nodes.name: passenger train station
description: A passenger train station is a train station for the exchange of passengers.

nodes.name: dispatch assignment
description: Dispatch assignment is a plan specification that refers to resource planning at a power plant (usually by the plant’s operator).

nodes.name: propulsion
description: Propulsion is an energy transformation that converts other forms of energy to kinetic energy.

nodes.name: demand trader
description: A demand trader is a trader that deals specifically with energy demand.

nodes.name: mathematical model
description: A mathematical model is a information content artifact that represents a system and its behaviours mathematically.

nodes.name: single axis tracking
description: Single axis tracking is solar tracking in which a radiation receiving surface is following the path of the sun by roting along a fixed axis. Typical axis orientations are North-South or East-West.

nodes.name: solar thermal power technology
description: A solar thermal power technology is a power generation technology that describes how to combine solar thermal power units in an electricity generation process with solar energy as input.

nodes.name: renewable power unit
description: A renewable power unit is a power generating unit that has the function to transform renewable energy.

nodes.name: sodium-ion battery
description: A sodium-ion battery is a rechargeable metal-ion battery that uses sodium ions as charge carriers.

nodes.name: primary energy carrier disposition
description: Primary energy carrier disposition is an energy carrier disposition of material entities that are extracted directly from natural resources or that are natural energy flows.

nodes.name: fixed cost
description: A fixed cost is a cost for operation and maintenance that does not vary with the amount of goods or services produced.

nodes.name: decrease
description: A process of becoming smaller, less numerous, less important, or less likely.

nodes.name: biogenic
description: Biogenic is an origin of portions of matter made by or produced from life forms.

nodes.name: market revenue
description: Market revenue is an economic value that represents the income from a trade at a market exchange.

nodes.name: heating oil
description: Heating oil is gas diesel oil for industrial and commercial uses, marine diesel and diesel used in rail traffic, other gas oil, including heavy gas oils which distil between 380 °C and 540 °C and which are used as petrochemical feedstocks.

nodes.name: greenhouse gas emission scenario
description: A greenhouse gas emission scenario is an emission scenario that describes a possible greenhouse gas emission trajectory.

nodes.name: scenario factsheet
description: A scenario factsheet is a factsheet that contains information about a scenario.

nodes.name: hard coal power technology
description: A hard coal power technology is a coal power technology that describes how to combine hard coal power units and hard coal in a fuel-powered electricity generation process.

nodes.name: physical method
description: A physical method is a method to calculate primary energy consumption that quantifies renewable and nuclear energies by attributing an efficiency value each.

nodes.name: merit order
description: A merit order is a plan specification that describes the dispatch ranking of power plants (electrical generation) based on ascending order of price.

nodes.name: reference role
description: A role of an information content entity, that indicates a benchmark, e.g. in a comparison.
editor_note: Although contradicting to BFO2, we add the reference role to the generically dependent "information content entity", aware of the ongoing discussion.

nodes.name: rotor diameter
description: Rotor diameter is a quality of a wind energy converting unit that measures the diameter of the wind rotor.

nodes.name: study subregion
description: A study subregion is a subregion of a study region.

nodes.name: spatial resolution
description: Spatial resolution is the resolution of a georeferenced dataset that indicates the geographical level of detail.

nodes.name: CO2 emission
description: A CO2 emission is an emission that releases carbon dioxide.

nodes.name: flexibility
description: Flexibility is a disposition of an energy system that is able to balance energy by adjusting energy supply and energy demand.

nodes.name: anthracite
description: Anthracite is a hard coal with a high caloric value due to its high carbon content (about 90 % fixed carbon).

nodes.name: canal
description: A canal is a transport network component that is an artificially created waterway.

nodes.name: service
description: A service is a process that is an intangible activity performed by some agent for the benefit of another agent.

nodes.name: unplanned availability
description: Unplanned availability is a quality that describes the amount of time a power plant is planned to be operational per year, but is not operation.

nodes.name: percent
description: "A dimensionless ratio unit which denotes numbers as fractions of 100." [Wikipedia:Wikipedia]

nodes.name: oil power unit
description: An oil power unit is a power generating unit using oil as fuel.

nodes.name: area per power unit
description: An area per power unit is a unit which is a measure for an area per nameplate capacity.

nodes.name: direct air capture
description: Direct air capture (DAC) is carbon dioxide capture from air.

nodes.name: PM2.5
description: PM2.5 is particulate matter which passes through a size-selective inlet as defined in the reference method for the sampling and measurement of PM2,5, EN 14907, with a 50 % efficiency cut-off at 2,5 µm aerodynamic diameter.

nodes.name: nitrogen dioxide
description: Nitrogen dioxide is a portion of matter with the chemical formula NO2. It is a gas and can act as an air pollutant.

nodes.name: melting
description: Melting is a phase transition from a solid medium to their liquid state.

nodes.name: waste and wastewater sector
description: A waste and wastewater sector is a sector that covers activities related the collection and treatment of waste and wastewater.

nodes.name: steam power unit
description: A steam power unit is a power generating unit that only has a steam turbine as turbine.

nodes.name: million ton of oil equivalent
description: A million ton of oil equivalent is an energy unit which is equal to 1,000,000 tons of oil equivalent.

nodes.name: memo item
description: A memo item is an information content entity about a sector that describes that the sector is excluded from some kind of total and only reported to provide further information (memo).

nodes.name: hydrogen fuel cell
description: A hydrogen fuel cell is a fuel cell that uses hydrogen.

nodes.name: marginal cost
description: Marginal cost is the economic value that corresponds to the change in the total cost that arises when the quantity produced is incremented by one unit; that is, it is the cost of producing one more unit of a good.

nodes.name: energy balance collection
description: An energy balance collection is a data set of energy balances for various time steps and/or temporal regions.

nodes.name: institution
description: An institution is an organisation that serves a social purpose.

nodes.name: state of matter
description: A state of matter is a quality of a portion of matter that describes the distinct physical form in which the matter exists.
editor_note: Four states of matter are observable in everyday life: solid, liquid, gas, and plasma. Many intermediate states are known to exist, such as liquid crystal, and some states only exist under extreme conditions.

nodes.name: sensible fluid heat storage object
description: A sensible fluid heat storage object is a sensible heat storage that uses fluids (like water, oil, …) to store thermal energy.

nodes.name: levelised cost of electricity
description: Levelised cost of electricity are the net cost of converting energy to electricity / electric energy over the lifetime of an energy transformation unit. They are calculated considering all relevant costs including investment, operation, maintenance and fuel cost, etc.

nodes.name: biogas power plant
description: A biogas power plant is a biofuel power plant that has biogas power units as parts.

nodes.name: methodical focus
description: A methodical focus is a model descriptor that specifies the primary calculation method used in a model.

nodes.name: slope
description: A slope is a quantity value with a plane angle unit that measures the angle between the plane of a surface and the horizontal plane.

nodes.name: gasworks gas
description:
Gasworks gas is manufactured coal based gas that covers all types of gases produced in public utility or private plants, whose main purpose is manufacture, transport and distribution of gas. It includes gas produced by carbonisation (including gas produced by coke ovens and transferred to gasworks gas), by total gasification with or without enrichment with oil products (LPG, residual fuel oil, etc.), and by reforming and simple mixing of gases and/or air, reported under the rows ‘from other sources’. Under the transformation sector identify amounts of gasworks gas transferred to blended natural gas which will be distributed and consumed through the natural gas grid.

The production of other coal gases (i.e. coke oven gas, blast furnace gas and oxygen steel furnace gas) should be reported in the columns concerning such gases, and not as production of gasworks gas. The coal gases transferred to gasworks plants should then be reported (in their own column) in the transformation sector in the gasworks plants row. The total amount of gasworks gas resulting from transfers of other coal gases should appear in the production line for gasworks gas.

nodes.name: hard coal power unit
description: A hard coal power unit is a coal power unit using hard coal as fuel.

nodes.name: contact person
description: A contact person is an agent that can be contacted for help or information about a specific service or good.

nodes.name: developable flow potential
description: A developable flow potential is a type of flow potential that describes the fraction of the economic potential that can be developed under realistic conditions (regulations, environmental and social restrictions).

nodes.name: thermal energy storage function
description: A thermal energy storage function is an energy storage function with thermal energy as input and output.

nodes.name: liquefied petroleum gas
description: Liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) is gas mixture of hydrocarbon gases, mainly propane and butane.

nodes.name: biogenic municipal waste fuel
description: A biogenic municipal waste fuel is a municipal waste fuel that has a biogenic origin.

nodes.name: diffuse solar radiation
description: Diffuse solar radiation is radiation that is the part of solar radiation that has been scattered by gas molecules in the atmosphere and by particles such as cloud droplets and aerosols.

nodes.name: marine wave energy
description: Marine wave energy is the natural hydro energy of a wave.

nodes.name: sensitivity analysis
description: A sensitivity analysis is the process of comparing different model calculations based on a variation of input parameters (exogenous data items).

nodes.name: gross national electricity consumption
description: Gross national electricity consumption is an energy consumption value measuring the consumption of electrical energy in a spatial region (e.g. a country), including gross electricity generation plus electricity imports, minus electricity exports. It is part of the gross inland energy consumption.

nodes.name: non-metallic mineral
description: A non-metallic mineral is a mineral that does not contain any metallic content within themselves. It is the physical output of an industrial process and has a commodity role.
editor_note: Some examples for non-metallic minerals are ceramic, glass, clay or gypsum.

nodes.name: bidding zone role
description: A bidding zone role is a role of a two-dimensional spatial region that is realised in market participants trading energy without capacity allocation.

nodes.name: delivery time
description: Delivery time is a one-dimensional temporal region expressing the amount of time that it takes for goods that have been bought to arrive at the place where they are wanted.

nodes.name: marine wave energy transformation
description: Marine wave energy transformation is a hydroelectric energy transformation that converts marine wave energy to electrical energy.

nodes.name: wind energy
description: Wind energy is the kinetic energy of moving air.

nodes.name: tank ship
description: A tank ship is a cargo ship used for the transport of liquid goods.

nodes.name: model intercomparison study
description: A model intercomparison study is a scenario study that performs a comparison of several models using a reference scenario.

nodes.name: wind
description: Wind is a process of air naturally moving.

nodes.name: fuel tank
description: A fuel tank is a tank that stores a combustion fuel.

nodes.name: top down
description: Top down is an analytical approach where design starts from the system as a whole. The system is then divided into smaller sub-applications with more details. Each part again goes through the top down approach till the complete system is designed with all minute details. Top down approach is also termed as breaking the bigger problem into smaller problems and solving them individually in a recursive manner. A top down model is based on a decomposition approach.

nodes.name: renewable electrolytic hydrogen
description: Renewable electrolytic hydrogen is electrolytic hydrogen that is produced with renewable electrical energy.

nodes.name: boiler
description: A boiler is a heater that increases the thermal energy of fluids.

nodes.name: net electricity generation
description: Net electricity generation is a process attribute that equals to gross electricity generation minus the consumption of power stations' auxiliary services.

nodes.name: gas fired power unit
description: A gas fired power unit is a power generating unit using gas as fuel.

nodes.name: scenario bundle
description: A scenario bundle is an information content entity that connects information about a scenario study and the associated scenario projections on the OEP via the OEKG.

nodes.name: operational space requirement
description: An operational space requirement is space requirement that covers the area needed by an artificial object in order to operate properly.

nodes.name: email address
description: An email address is an information content entity that identifies an email box to which messages are delivered.

nodes.name: photovoltaic energy transformation
description: Photovoltaic energy transformation is a solar energy transformation that converts solar energy into electrical energy.

nodes.name: nuclear binding energy
description: Nuclear binding energy is the energy that is required to disassemble the nucleus of an atom into its component parts.

nodes.name: economic life time
description: An economic life time is the operational life time during which an artificial object is profitable to the owner.

nodes.name: dam
description: A dam is an artificial object that stops or restricts the flow of water or underground streams.

nodes.name: direct solar radiation
description: Direct solar radiation is radiation that is the non-scattered part of solar radiation from the sun within the extent of the solar disk only.

nodes.name: yield profile
description: A yield profile is a generation time series of a particular renewable power plant.

nodes.name: marine tidal energy transformation
description: Marine tidal energy transformation is a hydroelectric energy transformation that converts kinetic energy from tidal flow to electrical energy.

nodes.name: grid connection cost
description: Grid connection costs are investment costs for establishing the grid connection from the energy generating device to point of connection to national grid.

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): solid waste disposal
description:
The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'solid waste disposal' is a waste and wastewater sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories:
Methane is produced from anaerobic microbial decomposition of organic matter in solid waste disposal sites.

nodes.name: EU emission sector: ETS stationary
description: The EU emission sector ETS stationary is a sector defined by an EU emission sector division that covers greenhouse gas emissions regulated by the European Union Emissions Trading System and that are emitted by stationary installations.

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): agriculture, forestry and fishing
description:
The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'agriculture, forestry and fishing' is an energy demand sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories:
Emissions from fuel combustion in agriculture, forestry, fishing and fishing industries such as fish farms.

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): photovoltaics
description:
The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'photovoltaics' is an industry sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories:
Photovoltaic cell manufacture may use and emit CF4 and C2F6 among others.

nodes.name: NC/BR sector: other
description: The NC/BR sector "other" is a sector defined by an NC/BR sector division that includes everything that is not included in the other NC/BR sectors. It aligns to the CRF sector (IPCC 2006): other.

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): aluminium production
description:
The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'aluminium production' is an industry sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories:
Aluminium Production covers primary production of aluminium, except the emissions related to the use of fuel. Carbon dioxide emissions result from the electrochemical reduction reaction of alumina with a carbon-based anode.
Tetrafluoromethane (CF4) and hexafluoroethane (C2F6) are also produced intermittently. No greenhouse gases are produced in recycling of aluminium other than from the fuels uses for metal remelting. Sulphur hexafluoride (SF6)
emissions are not associated with primary aluminium production; however, casting of some high magnesium containing alloys does result in SF6 emissions and these emissions are accounted for in Section 2C4, Magnesium
Production.

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): total emissions excluding LULUCF
description: The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'total emissions excluding LULUCF' is a sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories. It encompasses the following IPCC 2006 sectors: energy; industrial processes and product use; agriculture; waste; and other.

nodes.name: gaseous
description: The state of being a gas. A portion of matter is in gaseous state if and only if it has has no definite shape and no definite volume and is not electrically conductive.

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): ferroalloys production
description:
The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'ferroalloys' is an industry sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories:
Ferroalloys production covers emissions from primary metallurgical reduction production of the most common ferroalloys, i.e. ferro-silicon, silicon metal, ferro-manganese, silicon manganese, and ferro-chromium, excluding those
emissions relating to fuel use. From the production of these alloys, carbon dioxide (CO2), nitrous oxide (N2O), and methane (CH4) originating from ore- and reductant raw materials, is emitted.

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): multilateral operations
description:
The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'multilateral operation' is a transport sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories:
Emissions from fuels used for aviation and waterborne navigation in multilateral operations pursuant to the Charter of the United Nations.

nodes.name: MMR sector: M.International aviation in the EU ETS
description: The MMR sector 'M.International aviation in the EU ETS' is a transport sector that encompasses that part of the international aviation that is regulated by the European Union Emissions Trading System.

nodes.name: Effort Sharing Decision
description: The Effort Sharing Decision (ESD) is the European effort sharing for the years 2013-2020. It covers the European Union, Norway, Iceland and Liechtenstein and the following greenhouse gases: carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, hydrofluorocarbons, perfluorocarbons and sulphur hexafluoride. Emission quantities under the ESD are calculated using global warming potentials from the Fourth IPCC Assessment Report.

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): fluorochemical production
description: The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'fluorochemical production' is an industry sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories:

nodes.name: instantaneous
description: value measured at or modelled for exactly one 0-dim temporal region, referenced by a time stamp, e.g. to represent a time step in a time series

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): urea application
description: The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'urea application' is an agriculture, forestry and land use sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories

nodes.name: CRF sectors (IPCC 1996)
description: CRF sectors (IPCC 1996) is a version of the common reporting format that was used for national greenhouse gas inventories until the year 2014. It implements the Revised 1996 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories (with some deviations).

nodes.name: KSG sector waste management and other
description:
The KSG sector waste management and other is a sector defined by the KSG sector division. It is an aggregate of the following two sectors:
- CRF sector (IPCC 2006): waste (CRF 5)
- CRF sector (IPCC 2006): other (CRF 6)

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): transport
description:
The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'transport' is a transport sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories:
Emissions from the combustion and evaporation of fuel for all transport activity (excluding military transport), regardless of the sector, specified by sub-categories below. Emissions from fuel sold to any air or marine vessel engaged in international transport (1 A 3 a i and 1 A 3 d i) should as far as possible be excluded from the totals and subtotals in this category and should be reported separately.

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): product uses as substitutes for ozone depleting substances
description:
The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'product uses as substitutes for ozone depleting substances' is an industry sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories:
Hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) and, to a very limited extent, perfluorocarbons (PFCs), are serving as alternatives to ozone depleting substances (ODS) being phased out under the Montreal Protocol.

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): residential
description:
The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'residential' is a household sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories:
All emissions from fuel combustion in households.

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): biological treatment of solid waste
description:
The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'biological treatment of solid waste' is a waste and wastewater sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories:
Solid waste composting and other biological treatment. Emissions from biogas facilities (anaerobic digestion) with energy production are reported in the Energy Sector (1A4).

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): international bunkers and multilateral operations
description: The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) international bunkers is a transport sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories. It encompasses international bunkers and multilateral operation.

nodes.name: hourly
description: one value per hour

nodes.name: minimum
description: minimum value within a set of data values, e.g. in a time step or spatial region

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): other transportation
description:
The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'other transportation' is a transport sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories:
Combustion emissions from all remaining transport activities including pipeline transportation, ground activities in airports and harbours, and off-road activities not otherwise reported under 1 A 4 c Agriculture or 1 A 2. Manufacturing Industries and Construction. Military transport should be reported under 1 A 5.

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): cement production
description:
The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'cement production' is an industry sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories:
Process-related emissions from the production of various types of cement (ISIC: D2694).

nodes.name: end alignment
description: An end alignment is a time stamp alignment indicating that the time stamp marks the end of the time step.

nodes.name: plasmatic
description: The state of being a plasma. A portion of matter is in plasmatic state if and only if it has has no definite shape and no definite volume and is electrically conductive.

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): aerosols
description:
The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'aerosols' is an industry sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories:
Most aerosol packages now contain hydrocarbon (HC) as propellants but, in a small fraction of the total, HFCs and PFCs may be used as propellants or solvents. Emissions from aerosols usually occur shortly after production, on average six months after sale. During the use of aerosols, 100% of the chemical is emitted. The 5 main sources are metered dose inhalers (MDIs), personal care products (e.g. hair care, deodorant, shaving cream), household products (e.g. air-fresheners, oven and fabric cleaners), industrial products (e.g. special cleaning sprays such as those for operating electrical contact, lubricants, pipe-freezers) and other general products (e.g. silly string, tire inflators, claxons), although in some regions the use of such general products is restricted. The HFCs currently used as propellants are HFC 134a, HFC 227ea, and HFC 152a. The substance HFC 43 10mee and a PFC, perfluorohexane, are used as solvents in industrial aerosol products.

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): domestic navigation
description:
The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'domestic navigation' is a transport sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories:
Emissions from fuels used by vessels of all flags that depart and arrive in the same country (exclude fishing, which should be reported under 1 A 4 c iii, and military, which should be reported under 1 A 5 b). Note that this may include journeys of considerable length between two ports in a country (e.g. San Francisco to Honolulu).

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): rice cultivation
description:
The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'rice cultivation' is an agriculture, forestry and land use sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories:
Methane (CH4) emissions from anaerobic decomposition of organic material in flooded rice fields.

nodes.name: NC/BR sector: energy
description:
The NC/BR sector "energy" is a sector defined by an NC/BR sector division that includes all energy use that is not related to transport or industry. The sector includes:
- CRF sector (IPCC 2006): energy industry
- CRF sector (IPCC 2006): fuel combustion - other sectors
- CRF sector (IPCC 2006): fuel combustion - other
- CRF sector (IPCC 2006): fugitive emissions from fuels
- CRF sector (IPCC 2006): CO2 transport and storage

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): electronics industry - other
description: The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'electronics industry - other' is an industry sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): harvested wood products
description:
The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'harvested wood products' is an agriculture, forestry and land use sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories
CO2 net emissions or removals resulting from Harvest Wood Products.

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): other process uses of carbonates
description:
The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'other process uses of carbonates' is an industry sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories:
Includes limestone, dolomite and other carbonates etc. Emissions from the use of limestone, dolomite and other carbonates should be included in the industrial source category where they are emitted. Therefore, for example, where a carbonate is used as a flux for iron and steel production, resultant emissions should be reported under 2C1 “Iron and Steel Production” rather than this
subcategory.

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): metal industry - other
description: The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'metal industry - other' is an industry sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories:

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): enteric fermentation
description:
The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'enteric fermentation' is an agriculture, forestry and land use sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories:
Methane emissions from herbivores as a by-product of enteric fermentation (a digestive process by which carbohydrates are broken down by micro-organisms into simple molecules for absorption into the bloodstream). Ruminant animals (e.g., cattle, sheep) are major sources with moderate amounts produced from non-ruminant animals (e.g., pigs, horses).

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): heat transfer fluid
description:
The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'heat transfer fluid' is an industry sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories:
Heat transfer fluids, which include several fully fluorinated carbon compounds (either in pure form or in mixtures) with six or more carbon atoms, used and emitted during IC manufacture, testing and assembly. They are used in chillers, temperature shock testers and vapour phase reflow soldering.

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): foam blowing agents
description:
The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'foam blowing agents' is an industry sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories:
HFCs are being used as replacements for CFCs and HCFCs in foams, particularly in closed-cell insulation applications. Compounds that are being used include HFC-245fa, HFC-365mfc, HFC-227ea, HFC-134a, and HFC-152a. The processes and applications for which these various HFCs are being used include insulation boards and panels, pipe sections, sprayed systems and onecomponent gap filling foams. For open-cell foams, such as integral skin products for automotive steering wheels and facias, emissions of HFCs used as blowing agents are likely to occur during the manufacturing process. In closedcell foam, emissions not only occur during the manufacturing phase, but usually extend into the in-use phase and often the majority of emission occurs at the endof-life (de-commissioning losses). Accordingly, emissions can occur over a period of up to 50 years or even longer.

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): land use, land-use change and forestry
description: The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'land use, land-use change and forestry' (LULUCF) is an agriculture, forestry and land use sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories

nodes.name: EU emission sector: effort sharing
description: The EU emission sector effort sharing is a sector defined by the EU emission sector division that covers greenhouse gas emissions regulated by the Effort Sharing Decision and the Effort Sharing Regulation.

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): CO2 transport and storage - other
description:
The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'CO2 transport and storage' is a sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories:
Any other emissions from CCS not reported elsewhere.

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): maritime navigation
description: The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'maritime navigation' is a transport sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories. Emissions from fuels used by vessels of all flags that are engaged in international water-borne navigation. The international navigation may take place at sea, on inland lakes and waterways and in coastal waters. It includes emissions from journeys that depart in one country and arrive in a different country. It excludes consumption by fishing vessels.

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): other product manufacture and use
description:
The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'other product manufacture and use' is an industry sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories:
Emissions of sulphur hexafluoride (SF6) and perfluorocarbons
(PFCs) from the manufacture and use of electrical equipment and a number of other products. It also includes emissions of nitrous oxide (N2O) from several products.

nodes.name: MMR sector division
description: The MMR sector division is a sector division defined in Annex XII, Table 1 of Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 749/2014. It uses CRF sectors (IPCC 2006) and adds further sectors.
editor_note: Annex XII, Table 1 of Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 749/2014 https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/HTML/?uri=CELEX:32014R0749&from=EN#d1e32-67-1

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): adipic acid production
description:
The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'adipic acid production is an industry sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories:
Adipic acid is used in the manufacture of a large number of products including synthetic fibres, coatings, plastics, urethane foams, elastomers and synthetic lubricants. The production of Nylon 6.6 accounts for the bulk of adipic acid
use. The main greenhouse gas emitted from adipic acid production is nitrous oxide.

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): other product manufacture and use - other
description: The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'other product manufacture and use - other' is an industry sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): waste - other
description: The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'waste - other' is a waste and wastewater sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories

nodes.name: KSG sector division
description: The KSG sector division is a CRF-based sector division defined in annex 1 of the Bundes-Klimaschutzgesetz (KSG).

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): forest land
description:
The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'forest land' is an agriculture, forestry and land use sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories:
Emissions and removals from lands with woody vegetation consistent with thresholds used to define forest land in the national GHG inventory, sub-divided into managed and unmanaged, and possibly also by climatic region, soil type and vegetation type as appropriate. It also includes systems with vegetation that currently fall below, but are expected to later exceed, the threshold values used by a country to define the forest land category.

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): soda ash production
description:
The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'soda ash production' is an industry sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories:
Soda ash (sodium carbonate, Na2CO3) is a white crystalline solid that is used as a raw material in a large number of industries including glass manufacture, soap and detergents, pulp and paper production and water treatment. Emissions of CO2 from the production of soda ash vary dependent on the manufacturing process. Four different processes may be used to produce soda ash. Three of these processes, monohydrate, sodium sesquicarbonate (trona) and direct carbonation, are referred to as natural processes. The fourth, the Solvay process, is classified as a synthetic process.

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): electrical equipment
description:
The CRF sector (IPCC 2006) 'electrical equipment' is an industry sector defined by the 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories:
Electrical equipment is used in the transmission and distribution of electricity above 1 kV. SF6 is used in gasinsulated switchgear (GIS), gas circuit breakers (GCB), gas-insulated transformers (GIT), gas-insulated lines (GIL), outdoor gas-insulated instrument transformers, reclosers, switches, ring main units and other equipment.

nodes.name: CRF sector (IPCC 2006): railways
description:
issue: https://github.com/OpenEnergyPlatform/ontology/issues/580
pull request: https://github.com/OpenEnergyPlatform/ontology/pull/595
